Package org.jugsaxony.treed.api

Class AbstractBaseAnimationStrategy

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jugsaxony.treed.api.Utils
      • org.jugsaxony.treed.api.AbstractBaseAnimationStrategy
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AnimationStrategy, Constants
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractSparklingColor, DukeSaxony, ElectricStress, LeftFrontRightTop, MyStrategy, Pendulum, SearchLight, SnakeDown, SnakeUp, TeleLotto, VerticalRainbow, WarpEngine, XmasScrew
    public abstract class AbstractBaseAnimationStrategy
extends Utils
implements AnimationStrategy
    Convinence class implementing some of the interface methods to let you focus on only the important ones for your strategy. Also provides some helper methods inherited from Utils and breaks down processing all Bulbs of the list to processing each one at a time.

    • Field Summary

    • Method Detail

      • onStartAnimation

        public void onStartAnimation​(List<Bulb> bulbs,
                             long timestamp)
        Whenever your animation is started, this is the first method to be called by the framework. You can use it to set up internal data structures that will last for the whole animation. Please also tear down this data structures in #onEndAnimation.
        Specified by:
        onStartAnimation in interface AnimationStrategy
        Parameters:
        bulbs - The list of all bulbs gives you the number of them as well as the position and color of each one.
        timestamp - Provides a view at the clock ( System.currentTimeMillis() ) is a consistant way.

      • onStartFrame

        public void onStartFrame​(List<Bulb> bulbs,
                         long timestamp)
        The framework will present the animation as a sequence of frames and at the beginning of each frame, this method is called. You can use it to do some calculations that will have value for the whole frame. If you create a dynamic model of some sort in this method, please be a good citizen and destroy it in #onEndFrame.
        Specified by:
        onStartFrame in interface AnimationStrategy
        Parameters:
        bulbs - The list of all bulbs gives you the number of them as well as the position and color of each one.
        timestamp - Provides a view at the clock ( System.currentTimeMillis() ) is a consistant way.

      • onEndFrame

        public void onEndFrame​(List<Bulb> bulbs,
                       long timestamp)
        If you create a dynamic model of some sort in this method, please be a good citizen and destroy it in #onEndFrame.
        Specified by:
        onEndFrame in interface AnimationStrategy
        Parameters:
        bulbs - The list of all bulbs gives you the number of them as well as the position and color of each one.
        timestamp - Provides a view at the clock ( System.currentTimeMillis() ) is a consistant way.

      • onEndAnimation

        public void onEndAnimation​(List<Bulb> bulbs,
                           long timestamp)
        When your animation is ending, this is the last method to be called by the framework. You should use it to clean up after you. Thanks. BTW: It's not your decision, to end the animation. Only the framework has this superpower.
        Specified by:
        onEndAnimation in interface AnimationStrategy
        Parameters:
        bulbs - The list of all bulbs gives you the number of them as well as position and color of each one.
        timestamp - Provides a view at the clock ( System.currentTimeMillis() ) is a consistant way.

      • calcFrame

        public void calcFrame​(List<Bulb> bulbs,
                      long timestamp)
        Specified by:
        calcFrame in interface AnimationStrategy

      • calcBulb

        protected abstract void calcBulb​(Bulb bulb,
                                 long timestamp)
        This method is the essence of most animations. It determines the rgb color of the bulb depending on:
        • time
        • 3D position (x,y,z)
        • index (position in the sequence of bulbs)
        • old rgb color
        What a dry, mathematical way of looking at all your amazing animations. Sorry about that.
